quote: I didn't expect to be at the start line of the 2025 Belgian Waffle Ride in San Diego. Between a new job, family-wide respiratory illness, and a never-ending sleep deficit, this wasn't exactly the ideal lead-up to a 100-mile gravel race... We were two of just 21 women to finish the Waffle that day.

With 1,500 riders rolling out together, we got caught behind bottlenecks on early singletrack—losing nearly 45 minutes before the race even really began... At the second station, Keri took off, determined to beat the 11:30 a.m. deadline.

Just when we thought we were done, the course served us one last cruel combo: a dam, a lake, an eternal set of switchbacks, and the choice between a hike-a-bike or a creek crossing. We chose the creek—and slammed our bikes into hidden boulders. I went full submersion.

My goal was to make it over the climb in the 2nd group and I was right where I wanted to be after an 8-minute effort at 440 watts. Things went south quickly on the dirt though as I came around a corner and a rider was standing in the line fixing a dropped chain...

There was a puncture on the tread and near the tire bead. The sealant eventually worked but I had to air up multiple times and hold my bike sideways to get the sealant to pool at the puncture before sealing properly. I still had 15 miles of dirt to go until I saw pavement again...
Once I hit the Double Peak climb, I couldn't push my target power of 300 watts. I was pushing 270 and getting passed more than I should have.

Of 27 women who lined up for the 107-mile Belgian Waffle Ride, only 22 of us crossed the finish line. Meanwhile, 373 men started, and 355 finished... 8:20 later, I crossed the finish line. It felt like riding through quicksand, but I made it.

Right away, your bike handling skills and patience were tested—especially when we had a 15-minute walking section up a technical but mostly rideable section, but due to the crowds we slowly walked it all...

I rolled into an aid station, out of fluids and barely hanging on. Legitimately, I chugged two Cokes and had a saint of a volunteer fill my bottle before I slammed 120g of carbs just to get back in the game.

I chose to ride the Enve Melee with 48/35 chainrings, 10-36 cassette, and 35c Pirelli Cinturato Gravel H tires mounted on Zipp 303 Firecrest wheels at 44 PSI. I thought my setup would be quick on the pavement and have enough tire volume to be comfortable on dirt.
I am riding a Laugh true grit with 38 Specialized pathfinder pro tires and Victoria run flat inserts. I generally run about 30psi.

Somewhere in the chaos, I dropped my chain, lost Keri, missed a trail, and somehow ended up ahead of her. Once we reunited, we began the soul-crushing climb through what I now call Death Valley—aka Pamo Valley. A fierce headwind met us on the return.

After that, it was onto Lemontwist and Hodges—familiar stomping grounds—before splitting off from the Wafer route and heading up Highland Valley Road. Then came what felt like 97 turns through Ramona on dirt roads riddled with maxed-out potholes.

The race kicked off at 7am and hits a 1.7-mile road climb at mile 4 to break the field up before descending into the first dirt sector... we tackled the technical single track until I hit a square edged rock and felt my rear tire go soft... took another spill on a rain rutted downhill...

With 1,500 riders rolling out together, we got caught behind bottlenecks on early singletrack—losing nearly 45 minutes before the race even really began... we had a 15-minute walking section up a technical but mostly rideable section, but due to the crowds we slowly walked it all.

I hit a square edged rock and felt my rear tire go soft. There was a puncture on the tread and near the tire bead. The sealant eventually worked but I had to air up multiple times and hold my bike sideways to get the sealant to pool at the puncture before sealing properly.
My only option to avoid him lead me to crash into a wood post fence. Fortunately, the bike and I were ok, but I dropped 30 seconds to my group... took another spill on a rain rutted downhill.
We were two of just 21 women to finish the Waffle that day. Only about two-thirds of the 300 men finished.
The former road world champ got way behind at Belgian Waffle Ride California after he struggled to fix a flat 10 miles into the race.
We talk a lot about bike setup, nutrition, race results etc. but the best thing about these races is the people. Two friends invited me to stay in an Airbnb with two others I didn't know.
I would highly recommend any of the BWR events. They put on a good show, provide a lot of support, and the two courses I have done (Utah and California) have been challenging and unique.

Litespeed was on site at the Unroad Expo, and the vibe was high as racers brought their Litespeeds to our booth for complimentary pre-race service and safety checks, ensuring stem and seat binder bolts were to torque, ready for a bumpy day in the saddle.
Gravel isn't just harder than road—it's way more dynamic, and honestly, a lot more fun... It was brutal. It was suffering. And somehow, it was fun.
John, the absolute legend he is, was out there with SAG and moral support, shouting from the sidelines to catch up to a guy ahead. I did just that, tucking in behind him for a bit.

It was 2011 when just 136 people showed up for the first ever Belgian Waffle Ride. What it was was anyone's guess. Event organizer Michael Marckx envisioned an event in the spirit of the Belgian Classics; a road race with lots of dirt, hills and distance...
BWR CA benefits PeopleForBikes, an organization dedicated to making biking better for everyone.

Our friend Lance Haidet showed up in full form for BWR, and he brought his filmer along for the ride. Together, they put together an awesome video that covers the build-up, race-day action, and a spoken-word recap straight from Lance himself.

The day before the big event, we hosted the ALMSTHRE x BWR Shakeout Ride—and it turned into something pretty special. Over 100 riders showed up to preview key parts of the course, connect with the community, and get those pre-race jitters out.
